title: [BUG] Rich is too restrictive on dataclasses dependency
body:
**Describe the bug**
Few minutes ago I got some [pip install failures](https://github.com/ansible-community/molecule-podman/pull/25/checks?check_run_id=1459010189) which, IMHO are caused by being too restrictive regarding supported versions. 

```
py36:
rich 9.2.0 has requirement dataclasses<0.8,>=0.7; python_version >= "3.6" and python_version < "3.7", but you have dataclasses 0.8.
```

I know a bump happened on on Nov 10 but no release was made since. Still, I do think that the version compatibility range should not have a ceiling bound unless it is already known to break the library.

This is particularly problematic with rich which is mostly a library, so it needs to play well with other dependencies the project may need.

Lets assume you make 9.2.1 hotfix today to sort this issue. What happens if dataclasses makes release 0.9 tomorrow, it will likely get into conflict with rich again, even if there is no proof that they do not work together. This is even more problematic as the ceiling seams to be applied to the minor version.

If the concerns around possible breakage produced by dataclasses are real, at least the conditions should look more like `<1.0`.

title: [REQUEST] Allow RichHandler to receive custom log rendered class
body:
At this moment RichHandler does use a hardcoded LogRender and the only way to use an alternative one is to modify `_log_render` after instantiation.

**How would you improve Rich?**

I am more than happy to create a very small PR that allows user to specify which class to be used for log renderer. That is a no risk change to do as all existing code would default to current LogRender.

**What problem does it solved for you?**

This would allow implementation of other renderers, like one that does soft wrapping.

The current workaround of using of private attributes is dangerous as it could break on any new rich release.

title: [REQUEST] Make use of pre-commit for running linters
body:
I would like to suggest using [pre-commit](https://pre-commit.com/) tool (not hook!) for orchestrating linters during development. Currently rich has two linters: black and mypy*.

**How would you improve Rich?**

It would be much easier to run linting, much easier to enable additional checks (like newline consistency) and make is extremely easy to bump linters.

Projects like black, tox, pytest are already using it for a good number of years.

**What problem does it solved for you?**

It would make easier to test code locally before making a PR. 

If you do not have anything against it, I can easily make a PR to demonstrate it (probably less than 5min to do it).

title: [REQUEST] Respect PY_COLORS environment variable
body:
`PY_COLORS` is a [very popular](https://github.com/search?l=&q=PY_COLORS&type=code) method for forcing ANSI mode on or off in a command line application. 

Basically undefined means keeping application default behavior, likely auto-detection. Having it `PY_COLORS=0` means application will not use any ANSI codes and `PY_COLORS=1` will force ANSI mode regardless if terminal reports it or not.

For me personally is not a big deal as I already have code in applications I work with, but it would prove useful to have this directly into rich, so any user of rich would get this for free.

An implementation example can be seen at https://github.com/ansible-community/molecule/blob/20e1fa8a23308a9103e2dbdb4d3c4ae1ffe59c9d/molecule/logger.py#L42-L48

That is very useful feature to have when running on CI as you do not want to end-up defining 50-100 environment variables only to control ANSI behavior.

title: [BUG] Inconsistent formatting of file paths
body:
**Describe the bug**
I identified at least 3 different ways file-paths are rendered. The expected behavior would be to have a consistent formatting of these.

Apparently fully qualified paths are rendered correctly, but:

* relative paths are only partially colored (first two dots are missed)
* filenames without any path components are not highlighted at all

All these were printed using logging and simple strings. I tried to look if there is anything documented about how paths are rendered but I was not able to find info.

My guess is that some kind of hinting would be needed because it would be impossible to distinguish if a random string like "foo" is referring to a file or not. 

![sample](https://sbarnea.com/ss/Screen-Shot-2020-10-03-13-12-33.13.png)

title: [BUG] Rich is incompatible with pytest capsys fixture
body:
**Describe the bug**
Adopters of rich will eventually discover that their use of [capsys](https://docs.pytest.org/en/stable/capture.html) in pytest unittest gets broken when they integrate the library.

While this is somehow expected we should document a recipe for adapting testing in such way that does not break when using rich.

Example test:

```
import pytest

def test_output(capsys):
 	foo() # expected to produce stdout content
	stdout, stderr = capsys.readouterr()
	assert stdout == "..."
	assert stderr == "..."
```

This has repercussions even for logging functions and I even encountered errors when parametrizing tests like `ValueError: I/O operation on closed file.` which are caused by Console() instance being closed after the first test.

As rich itself makes use of pytest it should not be a big deal to include an example.

title: [REQUEST] Document lack of progressive printing on tables

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

body:
One issue with rich tables is that they render at the end and there is no way to gradually print tables row by row.

I can understand why this happens but for tools that produce long lists and likely ones that take significant time to produce for each row, this becomes a deal breaker.

I suspect that using a custom logger could be used to partially alleviate this limitation, at the cost of having less control over the final result.

From the rendering perspective, if user could define the column sizes when creating a table, it should be possible to perform gradual printing.

If this cannot be implemented due to current architecture, it may worth documenting this limitation and the logging workaround.

body:
## Type of changes

- [x] I've updated CHANGELOG.md and CONTRIBUTORS.md where appropriate.

## Description

Missing to specify encoding can mess some clients which may break the file encoding or render it incorrectly.

Example: file that loads ok locally, after upload to S3 gets broken if the encoding is not mentioned in file.

Use of UTF-8 is a very good practice, but we still need to mention it.

```
aws s3 cp report.html s3://bucket/report.html
```

The table drawing characters are those that are getting broken when not using UTF-8 but I can suspect that the same could happen with other Unicode characters too. [example](https://sbarnea.com/gri/ssbarnea.html) renders ok in Chrome but bad in Firefox, but once the charset is mentioned the issue is sorted.

Note: I don't think I deserve a mention in CONTRIBUTORS.md ;)

title: [BUG] use of stderr colorize trick breaks ability to produce ANSI on stderr
body:
**Describe the bug**
While this is an unlikely advanced use-case, I should better mention it, in hope we can find a workaround for it.

There is a shell trick that is used by some users in order to colorize output received on stderr with a different color, making easier to distinguish nature of output for programs producing output on both streams.

There are several implementations available as it may differ a little bit between platforms or shells but it mainly looks like https://github.com/cehoffman/dotfiles/blob/master/zsh/config#L174-L193  

What happens is that stderr is redirected to an unnamed pipe before being added an ANSI coloring sequence for each line. 

This works fine with one exception: programs that verify `sys.stderr.isatty()` as a side effect of this approach is that this is no longer reports true.

Programs that do use only `sys.stdout.isatty()` to determine if ANSI is supported or not are not affected, as ANSI still works on stderr.

I am not yet sure which is the best approach to avoid this issue as I see pros and cons for all cases. I do see some users wanting to avoid ANSI on stderr, for example if they redirect output for log files.

title: [REQUEST] Allow borderless rendering of Markdown code blocks
body:
Currently when we print code blocks (3-backticks based) they always get a free ANSI frame.

**How would you improve Rich?**

The presence of this frame prevents user from doing a copy/paste of that block because the ANSI frame characters will also be copied.

Please allow us to disable the frame rendering without preventing the code coloring, as this does not break the ability to copy/paste the code snippet.

I propose adding a new parameter to Markdown rendered in order to control its behavior.

title: Document RenderGroup and render_group decorator
body:
I am facing an adoption issue caused by the fact that it seems not possible to treat rendable objects as string and concatenate them. This seems related to recent https://github.com/willmcgugan/rich/issues/247 so I guess I am not the only one.

I had code that produced both Markdown and tables and I wanted to display it all at once. 

Before rich (or with classic ANSI) it was easy to concatenate the strings into a result and perform a print(result) at the end. 

**Details**

I have practical example at https://github.com/ansible/ansible-lint/pull/978/files where I am trying to print a list of rules using rich formatting. Our implementation allowed printing these using various formats where each format was a function returning a string.

Now, with rich this really become an issue because I cannot return a string to be printed. In fact, even if I switch to use console.print() in all cases I am unable to return what is to be printed because each rule renders as a table. That is why in my initial PR, I tried to do console.print(table) for each rule and return an empty string.

Obviously that my implementation is more of a hack, and not a nice one. Is there a better way to implement that?

My hope was that maybe `render()` would return a string that I can later print, but apparently it returns a generator, so clearly not something that I can concatenate and print later.

title: Long term project maintenance plans
body:
I liked rich as soon I found it and I would like to start using it on several CLI tools I am maintaining, like [ansible-lint](https://github.com/ansible/ansible-lint/pull/971) or [molecule](https://molecule.readthedocs.io/en/latest/). 

Still, I do have some concerns regarding long term future of the library as I see is hosted under a personal account. 

If you do not mind could you mention:
* are several cores available in case main contributor becomes unavailable?
* how willing to accept new cores?

Please note that this question is about risk mitigation. We all know how costly it can prove to fork or replace an unmaintained library. As I got my share of unlucky bets, now I am bit more cautious about adding new dependencies.
